preparation_steps: Test soil pH to 6.0-6.8 using digital meter 2-3 weeks before planting
Work 2-3 inches compost into top 8 inches soil when temperature reaches 50°F
Choose location with full sun receiving 6-8 hours direct sunlight daily
planting_steps: Start Carrots seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before 2025-05-10 at 70-75°F soil temperature
Sow seeds 0.5 inches deep with 2 inch spacing between plants
Transplant outdoors 2 weeks after 2025-05-10 when nighttime temperatures stay above 50°F
care_instructions: Water Carrots deeply 1-1.5 inches per week checking soil moisture 2 inches deep every 3 days
Apply 10-10-10 fertilizer at 2 tablespoons per plant every 3 weeks starting 2 weeks after transplant
Mulch with 2-3 inches organic matter keeping 6 inches away from plant stem
pest_management: Inspect Carrots weekly for common zone 4a-6a pests from May through September
Apply neem oil spray at 2 tablespoons per gallon water every 14 days if pests detected
Use floating row covers first 3 weeks after transplant to prevent early season pest damage
harvest_instructions: Begin harvesting Carrots approximately 70 days after transplant when fruits reach full size
Harvest in early morning 6-8 AM when temperatures below 75°F for best quality and flavor
Cut stems with clean sharp shears 1/4 inch above leaf node to encourage continued production
storage_tips: Store fresh Carrots at 55-60°F with 85% humidity for maximum 7-10 days after harvest
Blanch and freeze within 24 hours of harvest - maintains quality for 8-12 months in freezer
Preserve excess using canning or dehydrating methods appropriate for vegetable type

preparation_steps: Test soil pH to 6.0-7.0 using digital meter 2-3 weeks before planting
Work 2-3 inches compost into top 8 inches soil when temperature reaches 50°F
Choose location with partial shade receiving 6-8 hours direct sunlight daily
planting_steps: Start Lettuce seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before 2025-05-10 at 70-75°F soil temperature
Sow seeds 0.25 inches deep with 6 inch spacing between plants
Transplant outdoors 2 weeks after 2025-05-10 when nighttime temperatures stay above 50°F
care_instructions: Water Lettuce deeply 1-1.5 inches per week checking soil moisture 2 inches deep every 3 days
Apply 10-10-10 fertilizer at 2 tablespoons per plant every 3 weeks starting 2 weeks after transplant
Mulch with 2-3 inches organic matter keeping 6 inches away from plant stem
pest_management: Inspect Lettuce weekly for common zone 4a-6a pests from May through September
Apply neem oil spray at 2 tablespoons per gallon water every 14 days if pests detected
Use floating row covers first 3 weeks after transplant to prevent early season pest damage
harvest_instructions: Begin harvesting Lettuce approximately 45 days after transplant when fruits reach full size
Harvest in early morning 6-8 AM when temperatures below 75°F for best quality and flavor
Cut stems with clean sharp shears 1/4 inch above leaf node to encourage continued production
storage_tips: Store fresh Lettuce at 55-60°F with 85% humidity for maximum 7-10 days after harvest
Blanch and freeze within 24 hours of harvest - maintains quality for 8-12 months in freezer
Preserve excess using canning or dehydrating methods appropriate for vegetable type

plant_groupings.spacing_notes: Plant carrots in rows, 1-2 inches apart. Lettuce can be planted between carrot rows or in a separate section, 6-8 inches apart.

general_tips: Choose a sunny spot with well-draining soil for your garden. Carrots and lettuce prefer full sun to partial shade.
In Moncton's cold climate, start seedlings indoors 4-6 weeks before the last frost date (around May 15th) to give them a head start on the growing season.
Carrots are sensitive to temperature fluctuations, so make sure your soil is consistently moist but not waterlogged. Aim for a temperature range of 60-70°F (15-21°C).
Lettuce prefers cooler temperatures and can bolt (go to seed) in warmer weather. Plant it in early spring or late summer/early fall when the temperatures are cooler.
Moncton's growing season is relatively short, so make sure to plant cool-season crops like carrots and lettuce as soon as possible after the last frost date.
Use a raised bed or container garden if your soil is heavy clay or sandy. This will help improve drainage and aeration for your plants.
